Active Membership Inference Attack under Local Differential Privacy in Federated Learning


 


Truc Nguyen                        Phung Lai                        Khang Tran

University of Florida truc.nguyen@ufl.edu                        New Jersey Institute of Technology tl353@njit.edu                        New Jersey Institute of Technology kt36@njit.edu

NhatHai Phan                        My T. Thai*

New Jersey Institute of Technology phan@njit.edu                        University of Florida mythai@cise.ufl.edu

Abstract

Federated learning (FL) was originally regarded as a framework for collaborative learning among clients with data privacy protection through a coordinating server. In this paper, we propose a new active membership inference (AMI) attack carried out by a dishonest server in FL. In AMI attacks, the server crafts and embeds malicious parameters into global models to effectively infer whether a target data sample is included in a client’s private training data or not. By exploiting the correlation among data features through a non-linear decision boundary, AMI attacks with a certified guarantee of success can achieve severely high success rates under rigorous local differential privacy (LDP) protection; thereby exposing clients’ training data to significant privacy risk. Theoretical and experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that adding sufficient privacy-preserving noise to prevent our attack would significantly damage FL’s model utility.

1 INTRODUCTION

Federated Learning (FL) has emerged as a promising large-scale collaborative learning framework in recent years. By design, FL enables participating clients to collaboratively train a global model through a coordinating server. Although training data never leaves clients’ devices, a dishonest server can still infer the membership information of any client’s training data through observing their local model updates by using (passive or active) membership inference attacks [Shokri et al., 2017, Salem et al., 2019, Song and Mittal, 2021, Nasr et al., 2019]. For that reason, FL in its primitive form offers little to no privacy protection.

To address the problem, several privacy-preserving mechanisms, such as local differential privacy (LDP), have been developed to challenge membership inference (MI) attacks in general and active membership inference (AMI) attacks in particular by effectively protecting the membership information of client’s training data with upper-bounded privacy leakage [Arachchige et al., 2019, Sun et al., 2021, Lai et al., 2021, Lyu et al., 2020]. Recent studies apparently show that LDP protection is effective in mitigating MI and AMI attacks [Rahman et al., 2018, Bernau et al., 2021, Gu et al., 2022]. The key reason for this result is that existing attacks have not fully conveyed privacy risks in FL by under-exploiting the correlation among data features and LDP protection. That poses previously unexplored privacy risk to the clients’ local training data.

Key Contributions. To tackle that problem, we first formalize a new AMI threat model equipped with an AMI attack from a dishonest server. The key idea is that, given a target data sample, the server carefully crafts malicious weights of the global model such that the model updates from the clients would expose the membership information of the target data sample through the behavior of a chosen neuron. A chosen neuron is only activated given the target data sample controlled by a non-linear decision boundary embedded inside the malicious weights. With our non-linear decision boundary, the server can infer this membership information with severely high success rates. Furthermore, the server effortlessly achieves this result with a minimal change to the global model parameters within one training iteration.

In addition, we take a step forward and devise an AMI attack strategy under LDP protection to significantly amplify the privacy risk in FL. By adding a certain amount of privacy-preserving noise to the local data before training, LDP can protect the data with formal privacy leakage bounds (controlled by a privacy budget ε𝜀\varepsilon) [Dwork et al., 2014]. The key advantage of our AMI attack is exploiting the correlation among data features to distinguish the target data sample from others under LDP protection (Eq. 7). If LDP-preserving noise is insufficient to break this correlation (i.e., large privacy budgets ε𝜀\varepsilon), clients’ local data will be at risk of our AMI attack with certified guarantees of success. Meanwhile, large privacy-preserving noise (i.e., small privacy budgets ε𝜀\varepsilon) can significantly damage the FL’s model utility.

Our theoretical and experimental results in many benchmark datasets show that our AMI attacks stress-test the fundamental trade-offs between model utility and privacy risk in FL to a new level. This is reflected through notably high success rates under rigorous LDP protection (i.e., small privacy budgets ε𝜀\varepsilon which significantly degenerate FL’s model utility).

Organization.

The remainder of the paper is structured as follows. Section 2 presents background and establishes our threat model. Section 3 introduces our AMI attack from a dishonest server in FL. We devise an attack strategy under LDP protection with certified guarantees of success in Section 4. Section 5 evaluates the performance of AMI attacks in several benchmark datasets. Section 6 discusses related work and Section 7 provides concluding remarks.

2 BACKGROUND AND THREAT MODEL

In this section, we briefly review the background of federated learning and differential privacy, and then introduce our active membership inference threat model.

2.1 Background

Federated Learning (FL).

We focus on a horizontal setting of FL in which different clients hold the same set of features but different sets of samples. We denote fθ:ℝd→ℝk:subscript𝑓𝜃→superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑘f_{\theta}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{k} as a k𝑘k-class neural network model that is parameterized by a set of weights θ𝜃\theta. The aim of fθsubscript𝑓𝜃f_{\theta} is to map a data point x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} to a vector of posterior probabilities fθ​(x)=𝒴subscript𝑓𝜃𝑥𝒴f_{\theta}(x)=\mathcal{Y} over k𝑘k classes, where the sum of all values in 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y} is 1.

FL is an iterative learning framework for training a global model fθsubscript𝑓𝜃f_{\theta} on distributed data owned by N𝑁N different clients {uj}j=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑢𝑗𝑗1𝑁\{u_{j}\}_{j=1}^{N}. A central server coordinates the training of fθsubscript𝑓𝜃f_{\theta} by iteratively aggregating gradients computed locally by the clients. Let i∈ℤ≥0𝑖subscriptℤabsent0i\in\mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0} be the current iteration of the FL protocol, and θisuperscript𝜃𝑖\theta^{i} be the set of parameters at iteration i𝑖i. At iteration i=0𝑖0i=0, the global θisuperscript𝜃𝑖\theta^{i} is initialized randomly by the central coordinating server. At every iteration i𝑖i, a subset of M<N𝑀𝑁M<N clients is randomly selected to participate in the training. Each of the selected clients ujsubscript𝑢𝑗u_{j} receives fθisubscript𝑓superscript𝜃𝑖f_{\theta^{i}} from the central server and calculates the gradients Gjisuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑗𝑖G_{j}^{i} for fθisubscript𝑓superscript𝜃𝑖f_{\theta^{i}} using their local training batch 𝒟jsubscript𝒟𝑗{\cal D}_{j}. Specifically, Gji=∇θiℒ​(𝒟j,θi)superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑗𝑖subscript∇superscript𝜃𝑖ℒsubscript𝒟𝑗superscript𝜃𝑖G_{j}^{i}=\nabla_{\theta^{i}}\mathcal{L}({\cal D}_{j},\theta^{i}) where ℒℒ\mathcal{L} is a loss function. Then, each ujsubscript𝑢𝑗u_{j} uploads its gradients to the central server, who averages all of these gradients to compute the global model’s parameters with a learning rate η𝜂\eta:

Gi=1M​∑j=1MGji,θi+1=θi−η​Giformulae-sequencesuperscript𝐺𝑖1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑗𝑖superscript𝜃𝑖1superscript𝜃𝑖𝜂superscript𝐺𝑖G^{i}=\frac{1}{M}\sum_{j=1}^{M}G_{j}^{i},\quad\theta^{i+1}=\theta^{i}-\eta G^{i} (1)

The training continues until fθisubscript𝑓superscript𝜃𝑖f_{\theta^{i}} converges.

FL with Local Differential Privacy (LDP).

Recent attacks have shown that clients’ training data samples can be extracted from the shared gradients [Zhu et al., 2019, Yin et al., 2021]. These attacks underscore privacy risks in FL. Therefore, privacy-preserving mechanisms are needed to control and mitigate the privacy risks introduced by gradient sharing while optimizing utility.

Local differential privacy (LDP) [Dwork et al., 2006, Erlingsson et al., 2014] is one of the auspicious solutions, given its formal protection without an undue sacrifice in computation efficiency. LDP builds on the ideas of randomized response [Warner, 1965], which was initially introduced to allow survey respondents to provide their inputs while maintaining their confidentiality. The definition of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-LDP is as follows:

Definition 1.

ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-LDP. A randomized algorithm ℳℳ\mathcal{M} fulfills ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-LDP, if for any two inputs x𝑥x and x′superscript𝑥′x^{\prime}, and for all possible outputs 𝒪∈Range⁡(ℳ)𝒪Rangeℳ\mathcal{O}\in\operatorname{Range}(\mathcal{M}), we have: P​r​[ℳ​(x)=𝒪]≤eϵ​P​r​[ℳ​(x′)=𝒪]𝑃𝑟delimited-[]ℳ𝑥𝒪superscript𝑒italic-ϵ𝑃𝑟delimited-[]ℳsuperscript𝑥′𝒪Pr[\mathcal{M}(x)=\mathcal{O}]\leq e^{\epsilon}Pr[\mathcal{M}(x^{\prime})=\mathcal{O}], where ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is a privacy budget and Range⁡(ℳ)Rangeℳ\operatorname{Range}(\mathcal{M}) denotes every possible output of ℳℳ\mathcal{M}.

The privacy budget ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon controls the amount by which the distributions induced by inputs x𝑥x and x′superscript𝑥′x^{\prime} may differ. A smaller value of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon enforces a stronger privacy guarantee but reduces model utility.

2.2 Active Membership Inference Threat Model

Previous studies typically focus on a scenario in which the central server is interested in uncovering client information by examining local updates from the clients, but still abiding by the system protocol. This threat model is commonly referred to as honest-but-curious or semi-honest. However, this threat model undermines the vulnerability of the FL system as in practice, the server can deviate from the protocol to strengthen the privacy attacks [Boenisch et al., 2021, Nguyen et al., 2022, Fowl et al., 2021]. In this work, we are thus interested in explicitly malicious (or actively dishonest) servers that may modify the model architecture and/or model parameters before dispatching them to the clients. In this regard, we propose an active membership inference threat model, in which a dishonest server maliciously adjusts the model parameters to determine whether a target data sample is in the local training dataset of a client.

We describe the active membership inference threat model as follows. We denote 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} as the central server in FL, which is also the adversary. Note that this threat model represents an attack at an arbitrary iteration that targets a specific client. Let 𝒟={(xi,yi)}𝒟subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖\mathcal{D}=\{(x_{i},y_{i})\} be the batch of training data of the target client. The set 𝒟𝒟{\cal D} contains sample xi∈ℝdsubscript𝑥𝑖superscriptℝ𝑑x_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and its ground-truth label yi∈{1,…,k}subscript𝑦𝑖1…𝑘y_{i}\in\{1,...,k\} with k𝑘k classes. Suppose that 𝒟𝒟{\cal D} is sampled from a distribution 𝔻𝔻\mathbb{D} on (xi,yi)subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖(x_{i},y_{i}) that the adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} has knowledge of (i.e., similar to existing studies [Carlini et al., 2022, Yeom et al., 2018, Shokri et al., 2017]). This is practical in the real world since the server can collect a massive amount of data that covers the local data distribution of a sufficient number of clients [Shokri et al., 2017]. The adversary outputs maliciously crafted model parameters θ𝜃\theta to the target client. The client sends the local gradients G=∇θℒ​(𝒟,θ)𝐺subscript∇𝜃ℒ𝒟𝜃G=\nabla_{\theta}\mathcal{L}({\cal D},\theta) back to the adversary. By observing the local gradients G𝐺G, the goal of the server’s attack is to determine whether a target (data) sample t∈ℝd𝑡superscriptℝ𝑑t\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is included in the local training set 𝒟𝒟{\cal D}. More formally, the adversary can be defined as the following function:

𝒜𝔻:t,G→{0,1}:superscript𝒜𝔻→𝑡𝐺01\mathcal{A}^{\mathbb{D}}:t,G\rightarrow\{0,1\} (2)

where 𝒜𝔻superscript𝒜𝔻\mathcal{A}^{\mathbb{D}} denotes the query access to 𝔻𝔻\mathbb{D}, 1 means t∈𝒟𝑡𝒟t\in{\cal D}, and 0 otherwise.

We formalize this threat model as a security game 𝖤𝗑𝗉​(𝒜,ℒ,𝔻)𝖤𝗑𝗉𝒜ℒ𝔻\mathsf{Exp}{(\mathcal{A},\mathcal{L},\mathbb{D})} between a challenger and the adversary in Fig. 1. From that, the adversary’s advantage, or the attack success rate, is defined as follows:

Adv𝒜superscriptAdv𝒜\displaystyle\text{Adv}^{\mathcal{A}} =Pr⁡[𝖤𝗑𝗉​(𝒜,ℒ,𝔻)=1]absentPr𝖤𝗑𝗉𝒜ℒ𝔻1\displaystyle=\Pr[\mathsf{Exp}{(\mathcal{A},\mathcal{L},\mathbb{D})}=1] (3)
=12​Pr⁡[b′=1|b=1]+12​Pr⁡[b′=0|b=0]absent12Prsuperscript𝑏′conditional1𝑏112Prsuperscript𝑏′conditional0𝑏0\displaystyle=\frac{1}{2}\Pr[b^{\prime}=1|b=1]+\frac{1}{2}\Pr[b^{\prime}=0|b=0]

where Pr⁡[b′=1|b=1]Prsuperscript𝑏′conditional1𝑏1\Pr[b^{\prime}=1|b=1] is the True Positive Rate (TPR), and Pr⁡[b′=0|b=0]Prsuperscript𝑏′conditional0𝑏0\Pr[b^{\prime}=0|b=0] is the True Negative Rate (TNR). The success rate Adv𝒜superscriptAdv𝒜\text{Adv}^{\mathcal{A}} should be greater than 0.50.50.5, which is the probability of random guessing.

3 ACTIVE MEMBERSHIP INFERENCE (AMI) ATTACK

This section first discusses the technical intuition of membership inference through gradients. Based on this concept, we then describe our proposed strategy to launch the AMI attack from a dishonest server.

3.1 Inferring Membership via Gradients

As shown in Fig. 1, the adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} receives the gradients G𝐺G that was computed on the training set 𝒟𝒟{\cal D}, and 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} wishes to determine whether t∈𝒟𝑡𝒟t\in{\cal D}. This section discusses how the membership information can be inferred through gradients.

Suppose that, on an input data point x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, the output of the first fully-connected layer is expressed as ReLU⁡(W​x+b)=max⁡(0,W​x+b)ReLU𝑊𝑥𝑏0𝑊𝑥𝑏\operatorname{ReLU}(Wx+b)=\max(0,Wx+b) where W∈ℝr×d𝑊superscriptℝ𝑟𝑑W\in\mathbb{R}^{r\times d} is the weight matrix of that layer and b∈ℝr𝑏superscriptℝ𝑟b\in\mathbb{R}^{r} is the bias vector (r𝑟r is the number of neurons in the layer). To express the output of the i𝑖i-th neuron of that layer, we denote Wisubscript𝑊𝑖W_{i} as the corresponding row in the weight matrix and bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i} as the corresponding component in the bias vector. We observe that, when Wi​x+bi≤0subscript𝑊𝑖𝑥subscript𝑏𝑖0W_{i}x+b_{i}\leq 0, the ReLU outputs zero, in other words, the neuron i𝑖i is not activated by x𝑥x. As a result, the gradient of neuron i𝑖i, denoted by Gi(x)subscriptsuperscript𝐺𝑥𝑖G^{(x)}_{i}, is zero at the data point x𝑥x. Otherwise, when Wi​x+bi>0subscript𝑊𝑖𝑥subscript𝑏𝑖0W_{i}x+b_{i}>0, the gradient Gi(x)subscriptsuperscript𝐺𝑥𝑖G^{(x)}_{i} is non-zero.

As the gradient G𝐺G is computed over the whole training set 𝒟𝒟{\cal D}, the gradient of a neuron i𝑖i received by the adversary is the average of gradients over all data points x∈𝒟𝑥𝒟x\in{\cal D}, i.e., Gi=1|𝒟|​∑x∈𝒟Gi(x)subscript𝐺𝑖1𝒟subscript𝑥𝒟subscriptsuperscript𝐺𝑥𝑖G_{i}=\frac{1}{|{\cal D}|}\sum_{x\in{\cal D}}G^{(x)}_{i}. If there exists a neuron i𝑖i that is activated only by a target data sample t𝑡t (t∈ℝd𝑡superscriptℝ𝑑t\in\mathbb{R}^{d}), and not activated by any other data samples x≠t𝑥𝑡x\neq t, then we have:

{∑j=1dWi​j​tj>0∑j=1dWi​j​xj≤0,∀x∈𝒟∖t\left\{\begin{aligned} &\sum_{j=1}^{d}W_{ij}t_{j}>0\\ &\sum_{j=1}^{d}W_{ij}x_{j}\leq 0,\quad\forall x\in{\cal D}\setminus t\end{aligned}\right. (4)

note that we suppress the bias term for simplicity.

If t∈𝒟𝑡𝒟t\in{\cal D}, then Gisubscript𝐺𝑖G_{i} will be non-zero; otherwise, t∉𝒟𝑡𝒟t\notin{\cal D} results in Gisubscript𝐺𝑖G_{i} being zero. From that, the adversary upon seeing Gisubscript𝐺𝑖G_{i} can easily infer whether the target data sample t𝑡t was a part of the training set 𝒟𝒟{\cal D} or not. The formulation in Eq. (4) is similar to the framework proposed by [Boenisch et al., 2021] for conducting data reconstruction attacks where a neuron that is activated only by one sample can be used to perfectly reconstruct that sample. However, we shall see below that this simple formulation is actually inapplicable to the membership inference attack, thus requiring a more advanced strategy to launch the attack.

3.2 Attack Strategy: Manipulating Model Parameters via Training a Chosen Neuron

As aforementioned, if there exists a neuron that is activated only by the target data sample t𝑡t, it is sufficient to determine whether t𝑡t is in the training set 𝒟𝒟{\cal D} or not. From the threat model, the adversary can determine the model parameters θ𝜃\theta, which includes the weight matrix W𝑊W. Obviously, the adversary can choose some neuron i𝑖i and try to solve Eq. (4) for W𝑊W to realize the conditions of the chosen neuron. Since the adversary does not know 𝒟𝒟{\cal D}, it can only approximate Eq. (4) for all of its observed data samples x𝑥x that are different from t𝑡t (i.e., x≠t𝑥𝑡x\neq t and x∉𝒟𝑥𝒟x\notin\mathcal{D}). However, that makes Eq. (4) infeasible due to the linearity of the functions ∑j=1dWi​j​tjsuperscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑑subscript𝑊𝑖𝑗subscript𝑡𝑗\sum_{j=1}^{d}W_{ij}t_{j} and ∑j=1dWi​j​xjsuperscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑑subscript𝑊𝑖𝑗subscript𝑥𝑗\sum_{j=1}^{d}W_{ij}x_{j}, as shown in Appendix A.

To address this issue, we introduce non-linearity into the equation. To do so, instead of relying on the first layer, the adversary can choose a neuron in the second fully-connected layer such that the neuron is activated only by the target data sample t𝑡t, and not activated by any other data samples x≠t𝑥𝑡x\neq t. Let us denote h∈ℝrℎsuperscriptℝ𝑟h\in\mathbb{R}^{r} as the weight vector of the chosen neuron in the second layer, the attack is successful if we can find (h,W)ℎ𝑊(h,W) such that:

{∑i=1rhi​ReLU⁡(∑j=1dWi​j​tj)>0∑i=1rhi​ReLU⁡(∑j=1dWi​j​xj)≤0,∀x≠t\left\{\begin{aligned} &\sum_{i=1}^{r}h_{i}\operatorname{ReLU}(\sum_{j=1}^{d}W_{ij}t_{j})>0\\ &\sum_{i=1}^{r}h_{i}\operatorname{ReLU}(\sum_{j=1}^{d}W_{ij}x_{j})\leq 0,\quad\forall x\neq t\end{aligned}\right. (5)

To solve Eq. (5), we can train the chosen neuron to be activated only by the target data sample t𝑡t. For the training, we first put forth a logistic sigmoid function (σ𝜎\sigma) on the output of the chosen neuron. As a result, the function of the chosen neuron becomes:

s​(x)𝑠𝑥\displaystyle s(x) =σ​(∑i=1rhi​ReLU⁡(∑j=1dWi​j​xj))absent𝜎superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑟subscriptℎ𝑖ReLUsuperscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑑subscript𝑊𝑖𝑗subscript𝑥𝑗\displaystyle=\sigma(\sum_{i=1}^{r}h_{i}\operatorname{ReLU}(\sum_{j=1}^{d}W_{ij}x_{j})) (6)
=σ​(h⋅ReLU⁡(W​x))absent𝜎⋅ℎReLU𝑊𝑥\displaystyle=\sigma(h\cdot\operatorname{ReLU}(Wx))

Next, we sample a dataset 𝒳∼𝔻msimilar-to𝒳superscript𝔻𝑚\mathcal{X}\sim\mathbb{D}^{m}, in which we assign a label 111 for the target data sample t𝑡t and label 00 for all other data samples x∈𝒳∖t𝑥𝒳𝑡x\in\mathcal{X}\setminus t. After that, we train the chosen neuron using cross-entropy loss. The key idea is that the training process tries to make s​(t)=1𝑠𝑡1s(t)=1, and s​(x)=0𝑠𝑥0s(x)=0 for x≠t𝑥𝑡x\neq t. When s​(t)>0.5𝑠𝑡0.5s(t)>0.5, it means that h⋅ReLU⁡(W​t)>0⋅ℎReLU𝑊𝑡0h\cdot\operatorname{ReLU}(Wt)>0; otherwise, when s​(x)<0.5𝑠𝑥0.5s(x)<0.5, we have h⋅ReLU⁡(W​x)<0⋅ℎReLU𝑊𝑥0h\cdot\operatorname{ReLU}(Wx)<0 and that conforms to Eq. (5).

When the adversary receives the gradient G𝐺G, it can observe the gradient of that chosen neuron to determine whether the target data sample t𝑡t is in the training set 𝒟𝒟{\cal D} (t∈𝒟𝑡𝒟t\in{\cal D}) or not, as discussed in the previous section. In particular, the adversary extracts the gradient of the chosen neuron, denoted by gtsubscript𝑔𝑡g_{t}, from G𝐺G and sees whether gtsubscript𝑔𝑡g_{t} is non-zero. If gtsubscriptgtg_{t} is zero, the adversary predicts that the target data sample ttt is not in the training set 𝒟𝒟{\cal D} (i.e., t∉𝒟𝑡𝒟t\notin{\cal D}). This is because the chosen neuron was not activated during the gradient computation on the training set 𝒟𝒟{\cal D}. Otherwise, if gtsubscriptgtg_{t} is non-zero, then the adversary predicts that the target data sample ttt is in the training set 𝒟𝒟{\cal D} (i.e., t∈𝒟𝑡𝒟t\in{\cal D}).

Fig. 2 shows a design of the adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} according to the threat model in Fig. 1. Note that our attack strategy only modifies the parameters of 1 chosen neuron in the second layer and r𝑟r associated neurons in the first layer. That makes our attack feasible by enabling us to make a minimal change to the model parameters, and the attack can be carried out within one FL training iteration.

4 AMI ATTACK UNDER LDP WITH CERTIFIED GUARANTEE OF SUCCESS

LDP is generally regarded as an effective defense against privacy inference attacks given its rigorous privacy protection compared with other approaches [Wagh et al., 2021]. To tolerate such mechanisms, our AMI attack exploits the correlation among input features captured through a non-linear decision boundary to distinguish the target data sample t𝑡t from others (Eq. 5) under LDP protection. If LDP-preserving noise is insufficient to break this correlation (i.e., large privacy budgets ε𝜀\varepsilon), clients’ local data will be at risk of our AMI attack. Meanwhile, large privacy-preserving noise (i.e., small privacy budgets ε𝜀\varepsilon) can significantly damage the model utility. In FL, it is challenging for clients to identify suitable privacy budgets given their limited local training data. Therefore, they usually rely on the server to provide the privacy budget ε𝜀\varepsilon and the LDP-preserving mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M}. That increases the risk of exposing their local training data to a dishonest server under our AMI attack. We focus on shedding light on the fundamental trade-offs between ε𝜀\varepsilon-LDP protection, model utility, and privacy risk with a certified bound for our AMI attack to be successful.

Each client independently perturbs every training data sample in their local training data 𝒟𝒟{\cal D} using an LDP-preserving mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M} (Def. 1) to obtain a randomized local training set 𝒟′=ℳ​(𝒟,ε)={ℳ​(x,ε)}x∈𝒟superscript𝒟′ℳ𝒟𝜀subscriptℳ𝑥𝜀𝑥𝒟{\cal D}^{\prime}=\mathcal{M}({\cal D},\varepsilon)=\{\mathcal{M}(x,\varepsilon)\}_{x\in{\cal D}}. The client sends the gradients derived from the randomized training set G=∇θℒ​(𝒟′,θ)𝐺subscript∇𝜃ℒsuperscript𝒟′𝜃G=\nabla_{\theta}\mathcal{L}({\cal D}^{\prime},\theta) to the server. The mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M} and the privacy budget ε𝜀\varepsilon are known to the adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, thus, the adversary function in Eq. (2) is re-defined under LDP context as 𝒜L​D​P𝔻,ℳ:t,G,ε→{0,1}:subscriptsuperscript𝒜𝔻ℳ𝐿𝐷𝑃→𝑡𝐺𝜀01\mathcal{A}^{\mathbb{D},\mathcal{M}}_{LDP}:t,G,\varepsilon\rightarrow\{0,1\}. We enhance the threat model to reflect the use of LDP in Fig. 3.

Attack Strategy.

Given the gradients G𝐺G computed on LDP-perturbed data 𝒟′superscript𝒟′{\cal D}^{\prime}, applying the same attack strategy that was discussed in Section 3.2 would not work effectively. Suppose that the target sample t𝑡t is in 𝒟𝒟{\cal D}, and that the adversary were able to train a neuron that is activated only by the target sample t𝑡t, i.e., h⋅ReLU⁡(W​t)>0⋅ℎReLU𝑊𝑡0h\cdot\operatorname{ReLU}(Wt)>0 and h⋅ReLU⁡(W​x)<0⋅ℎReLU𝑊𝑥0h\cdot\operatorname{ReLU}(Wx)<0 for x≠t𝑥𝑡x\neq t. However, it is very likely that t𝑡t is not in the randomized local training set 𝒟′superscript𝒟′{\cal D}^{\prime} since t𝑡t was randomized under LDP. As the client uses 𝒟′superscript𝒟′{\cal D}^{\prime} for gradients computation, the chosen neuron may remain inactivated, i.e., h⋅ReLU⁡(W⋅ℳ​(t,ε))<0⋅ℎReLU⋅𝑊ℳ𝑡𝜀0h\cdot\operatorname{ReLU}(W\cdot\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon))<0. Hence, the attack fails to infer the correct membership of t𝑡t.

Therefore, it is necessary for the adversary to ensure that the chosen neuron is activated only by the randomized target sample ℳ​(t,ε)ℳ𝑡𝜀\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon). Similar to Eq. (5), we formulate this observation as finding (h,W)ℎ𝑊(h,W) such that:

{h⋅ReLU⁡(W​ℳ​(t,ε))>0h⋅ReLU⁡(W​x)≤0,∀x≠ℳ​(t,ε)\left\{\begin{aligned} &h\cdot\operatorname{ReLU}(W\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon))>0\\ &h\cdot\operatorname{ReLU}(Wx)\leq 0,\quad\forall x\neq\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon)\end{aligned}\right. (7)

To develop an effective attack for Eq. (7), it is essential for the chosen neuron to be activated if the client uses ℳ​(t,ε)ℳ𝑡𝜀\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon) regardless of the randomness introduced by the LDP-preserving mechanism ℳ​(⋅,ε)ℳ⋅𝜀\mathcal{M}(\cdot,\varepsilon). To achieve our goal, we strengthen our attack by generating a set 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} of l𝑙l perturbations ℳ​(t,ε)ℳ𝑡𝜀\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon), that is, invoking ℳ​(t,ε)ℳ𝑡𝜀\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon) l𝑙l times with independent draws of LDP-preserving noise. Next, we sample a training set 𝒳∼𝔻msimilar-to𝒳superscript𝔻𝑚\mathcal{X}\sim\mathbb{D}^{m} such that 𝒳∩𝒯=∅𝒳𝒯\mathcal{X}\cap\mathcal{T}=\emptyset. Then, we assign label 111 for samples in 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} (which contains randomized versions of t𝑡t) and label 00 for samples in 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}. Finally, we train the chosen neuron using cross-entropy loss. The remaining steps follow Section 3.2. Fig. 4 shows the design of the adversary 𝒜L​D​Psubscript𝒜𝐿𝐷𝑃\mathcal{A}_{LDP} with respect to the threat model in Fig. 3.

Certified Guarantee of Success for AMI.

Now, we derive certified guarantees for the adversary (Fig. 4) to be successful under ε𝜀\varepsilon-LDP protection. The AMI attack 𝒜L​D​P𝔻,ℳsubscriptsuperscript𝒜𝔻ℳ𝐿𝐷𝑃\mathcal{A}^{\mathbb{D},\mathcal{M}}_{LDP} is successful in determining the membership of the target sample t𝑡t if it can ensure that the chosen neuron is activated only by the LDP-preserving ℳ​(t,ε)ℳ𝑡𝜀\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon). Following the expected output stability property in DP [Lecuyer et al., 2019], in which the expected value of an ε𝜀\varepsilon-LDP algorithm with bounded output is not sensitive to small changes in the input, the trained attack 𝒜L​D​P𝔻,ℳsubscriptsuperscript𝒜𝔻ℳ𝐿𝐷𝑃\mathcal{A}^{\mathbb{D},\mathcal{M}}_{LDP} is certifiably robust to ℳ​(⋅,ε)ℳ⋅𝜀\mathcal{M}(\cdot,\varepsilon) if the following condition holds:

{𝔼​[v​(t)]>0𝔼​[v​(x)]≤0,x≠ℳ​(t,ε)\left\{\begin{aligned} &\mathbb{E}\big{[}v(t)\big{]}>0\\ &\mathbb{E}\big{[}v(x)\big{]}\leq 0,\quad x\neq\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon)\end{aligned}\right. (8)

where v​(t)=h⋅ReLU⁡(W​ℳ​(t,ε))𝑣𝑡⋅ℎReLU𝑊ℳ𝑡𝜀v(t)=h\cdot\operatorname{ReLU}(W\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon)) and v​(x)=h⋅ReLU⁡(W​x)𝑣𝑥⋅ℎReLU𝑊𝑥v(x)=h\cdot\operatorname{ReLU}(Wx) are the values of the chosen neuron, given the randomized target sample ℳ​(t,ε)ℳ𝑡𝜀\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon) and any other data samples x≠ℳ​(t,ε)𝑥ℳ𝑡𝜀x\neq\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon), respectively.

However, due to the potentially complex nature of the post-noise computation, we cannot precisely compute the expectations in Eq. (8). We therefore resort to Monte Carlo sampling to estimate the expectations 𝔼^​(⋅)^𝔼⋅\hat{\mathbb{E}}(\cdot). This estimation is obtained by invoking ℳ​(⋅)ℳ⋅\mathcal{M}(\cdot) multiple times with independent draws of the noise over the input. We denote vp​(t)subscript𝑣𝑝𝑡v_{p}(t) as the p𝑝p draws of ℳ​(t,ε)ℳ𝑡𝜀\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon) from the target sample t𝑡t and vq​(x)subscript𝑣𝑞𝑥v_{q}(x) as the q𝑞q draws of ℳ​(x,ε)ℳ𝑥𝜀\mathcal{M}(x,\varepsilon) from the sample x𝑥x. Then, we replace 𝔼​[v​(t)]𝔼delimited-[]𝑣𝑡\mathbb{E}\big{[}v(t)\big{]} with 𝔼^​[v​(t)]=1p​∑pvp​(t)^𝔼delimited-[]𝑣𝑡1𝑝subscript𝑝subscript𝑣𝑝𝑡\hat{\mathbb{E}}\big{[}v(t)\big{]}=\frac{1}{p}\sum_{p}v_{p}(t) and replace 𝔼​[v​(x)]𝔼delimited-[]𝑣𝑥\mathbb{E}\big{[}v(x)\big{]} with 𝔼^​[v​(x)]=1q​∑qvq​(x)^𝔼delimited-[]𝑣𝑥1𝑞subscript𝑞subscript𝑣𝑞𝑥\hat{\mathbb{E}}\big{[}v(x)\big{]}=\frac{1}{q}\sum_{q}v_{q}(x), where p𝑝p an q𝑞q are the number of invocations of ℳ​(⋅)ℳ⋅\mathcal{M}(\cdot) for t𝑡t and x𝑥x, respectively.

The key idea is to simultaneously ensure that the lower bound 𝔼^l​b​[v​(t)]superscript^𝔼𝑙𝑏delimited-[]𝑣𝑡\hat{\mathbb{E}}^{lb}\big{[}v(t)\big{]} is larger than 00 and the upper bound 𝔼^u​b​[v​(x)]superscript^𝔼𝑢𝑏delimited-[]𝑣𝑥\hat{\mathbb{E}}^{ub}\big{[}v(x)\big{]} is smaller than or equal to 00 with a broken probability δ𝛿\delta. That provides a certified guarantee for the Eq. (8) to hold. We compute (1−δ)1𝛿(1-\delta)-confidence the lower bound 𝔼^l​b​[v​(t)]superscript^𝔼𝑙𝑏delimited-[]𝑣𝑡\hat{\mathbb{E}}^{lb}\big{[}v(t)\big{]} and the upper bound 𝔼^u​b​[v​(x)]superscript^𝔼𝑢𝑏delimited-[]𝑣𝑥\hat{\mathbb{E}}^{ub}\big{[}v(x)\big{]} by using Hoeffding’s inequality [Hoeffding, 1963], as follows:

𝔼^l​b​[v​(t)]≜𝔼^​[v​(t)]−Range⁡(v​(t))​−ln⁡(δ)2​p≜superscript^𝔼𝑙𝑏delimited-[]𝑣𝑡^𝔼delimited-[]𝑣𝑡Range𝑣𝑡𝛿2𝑝\displaystyle\hat{\mathbb{E}}^{lb}\big{[}v(t)\big{]}\triangleq\hat{\mathbb{E}}\big{[}v(t)\big{]}-\operatorname{Range}\big{(}v(t)\big{)}\sqrt{-\frac{\ln(\delta)}{2p}} (9)
𝔼^u​b​[v​(x)]≜𝔼^​[v​(x)]+Range⁡(v​(x))​−ln⁡(δ)2​q≜superscript^𝔼𝑢𝑏delimited-[]𝑣𝑥^𝔼delimited-[]𝑣𝑥Range𝑣𝑥𝛿2𝑞\displaystyle\hat{\mathbb{E}}^{ub}\big{[}v(x)\big{]}\triangleq\hat{\mathbb{E}}\big{[}v(x)\big{]}+\operatorname{Range}\big{(}v(x)\big{)}\sqrt{-\frac{\ln(\delta)}{2q}} (10)

where Range⁡(v​(⋅))Range𝑣⋅\operatorname{Range}\big{(}v(\cdot)\big{)} is the range of v​(⋅)𝑣⋅v(\cdot).

By replacing the bounds in Eqs. (9) and (10) to the expectations in Eq. (8), we derive the certified guarantee so that Eq. (8) holds as in Theorem 11.

Theorem 1.

(Certified Guarantee Condition) Suppose that clients in FL apply the LDP-preserving ℳ​(⋅,ε)ℳ⋅𝜀\mathcal{M}(\cdot,\varepsilon) to their local data. 𝔼^l​b​[v​(t)]superscript^𝔼𝑙𝑏delimited-[]𝑣𝑡\hat{\mathbb{E}}^{lb}\big{[}v(t)\big{]} and 𝔼^u​b​[v​(x)]superscript^𝔼𝑢𝑏delimited-[]𝑣𝑥\hat{\mathbb{E}}^{ub}\big{[}v(x)\big{]}, computed as in Eqs. 9 and 10, are the (1−δ)1𝛿(1-\delta)-confidence lower and upper bounds, respectively. The AMI attack 𝒜L​D​P𝔻,ℳsubscriptsuperscript𝒜𝔻ℳ𝐿𝐷𝑃\mathcal{A}^{\mathbb{D},\mathcal{M}}_{LDP} is successful in inferring the membership of the target sample t𝑡t in 𝔻𝔻\mathbb{D} if the following condition is satisfied:

{𝔼^l​b​[v​(t)]>0𝔼^u​b​[v​(x)]≤0,x≠ℳ​(t,ε)\left\{\begin{aligned} &\hat{\mathbb{E}}^{lb}\big{[}v(t)\big{]}>0\\ &\hat{\mathbb{E}}^{ub}\big{[}v(x)\big{]}\leq 0,\quad x\neq\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon)\end{aligned}\right. (11)

Proof of Theorem 11 is in Appendix B. At the attack time, we implement a certified guarantee of success as a search to return the minimal privacy budget ε𝜀\varepsilon and broken probability δ𝛿\delta so that the condition in Theorem 11 holds, as follows:

Corollary 1.

Given a well-trained model fθsubscript𝑓𝜃f_{\theta} and the target sample t𝑡t, the AMI attack 𝒜L​D​P𝔻,ℳsubscriptsuperscript𝒜𝔻ℳ𝐿𝐷𝑃\mathcal{A}^{\mathbb{D},\mathcal{M}}_{LDP} is guaranteed to be successful up to the privacy budget ε∗superscript𝜀\varepsilon^{*} and the broken probability δ∗superscript𝛿\delta^{*} for which the condition in Theorem 11 checks out:

(ε∗,δ∗)=argminε,δs.t.{𝔼^l​b​[h⋅ReLU⁡(W​ℳ​(t,ε))]>0𝔼^u​b​[h⋅ReLU⁡(W​x)]≤0,x≠ℳ​(t,ε)(\varepsilon^{*},~{}\delta^{*}){=}\arg\min_{\varepsilon,\delta}~{}\text{s.t.}~{}\left\{\begin{aligned} &\hat{\mathbb{E}}^{lb}\big{[}h\cdot\operatorname{ReLU}(W\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon))\big{]}>0\\ &\hat{\mathbb{E}}^{ub}\big{[}h\cdot\operatorname{ReLU}(Wx)\big{]}\leq 0,x{\neq}\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon)\end{aligned}\right. (12)

Since the mechanism ℳ​(⋅)ℳ⋅\mathcal{M}(\cdot) and the privacy budget ε𝜀\varepsilon are known to the adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, we only do a line search to find the minimal δ𝛿\delta for a given ε∗superscript𝜀\varepsilon^{*}.

5 EVALUATION

This section validates the effectiveness of our AMI attack by gauging its success rate. We particularly focus on evaluating how well it performs under LDP protection. Our implementation of the attack is available at https://github.com/trucndt/ami.

Experimental Settings.

We evaluate AMI attack with three benchmark datasets, including CIFAR-10 [Krizhevsky et al., 2009], ImageNet [Deng et al., 2009], and CelebA [Liu et al., 2015]. Each dataset includes a training set and a validation set. The training set is used to sample the local training set 𝒟𝒟{\cal D} in the threat model (Figs. 1 and 3), while the validation set is used as the sampled set 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} of the adversary. Our experiment follows the security game in Figs. 1 and 3, and the success rate is calculated using Eq. (3) after executing the game 10,000 times. The batch size |𝒟|𝒟|{\cal D}| is chosen to be 20 for the CelebA dataset according to its specification (i.e., 20 face images per person). As in [Fowl et al., 2021, Boenisch et al., 2021, Geiping et al., 2020], we set |𝒟|𝒟|{\cal D}| to 64 and 100 for the ImageNet and CIFAR-10 datasets, respectively. We modify r=1,000𝑟1000r=1,000 neurons in the first layer and 1 neuron in the second layer to carry out AMI attacks. Further details on the experimental settings can be found in Appendix D.

To realize ℳℳ\mathcal{M} in Fig. 3, we use two different LDP mechanisms: OME [Lyu et al., 2020] and BitRand [Lai et al., 2021]. These mechanisms add LDP noises to the embeddings of data samples. Such embeddings are obtained via a pre-trained Resnet-18 model which results in feature vectors of 512 dimensions [He et al., 2016]. We show the results when using BitRand in this section and refer the readers to Appendix D for the results on OME. A background on BitRand and OME is provided in Appendix C.

Attack Performance without LDP.

In three datasets, our attack achieves near 100% success rate. The key reason behind this impressive success rate is that our attack strategy can easily train the chosen neuron to satisfy the attack objective, i.e., Eq. (5). Intuitively, the problem formulation in Eq. (5) is equivalent to finding a decision boundary over-fitting to t𝑡t in a way that can distinguish t𝑡t against all other samples. As a result, increasing the number of neurons in the first layer (r𝑟r) helps improve the attack performance, as it makes the model more over-fitting. In our experiments, we can achieve a 100% success rate with as few as 5 neurons (r=5𝑟5r=5) in the first layer. We refer the readers to Appendix D for further analysis of this scenario as we focus the rest of this section on evaluating the attack under LDP.

Attack Performance under LDP.

Fig. 5 shows that our attack introduces severe privacy risk to clients’ local training data through strong attack success rates under LDP protection. Large privacy budgets ε𝜀\varepsilon (e.g., ε≥5𝜀5\varepsilon\geq 5) does minimal to defend against our AMI attack. Across all three datasets, the model accuracy on the legitimate classification task remains acceptable given ε≥5𝜀5\varepsilon\geq 5. However, our attack imposes a severely high success rate (≥0.77absent0.77\geq 0.77), which approaches a near perfect success rate of 0.990.990.99 with ε≥9𝜀9\varepsilon\geq 9. When we reduce the privacy budget (ε∈[3,4]𝜀34\varepsilon\in[3,4]), our attack still maintains a success rate of at least 0.67, 0.58, and 0.62, on CelebA, ImageNet, and CIFAR-10, respectively. With very low ε𝜀\varepsilon (ε∈[1,2]𝜀12\varepsilon\in[1,2]), the model accuracy is severely damaged.

Furthermore, Fig. 5 depicts the TPR and TNR of our attack. Recall that TPR denotes how well the attack detects the presence of the target sample t𝑡t in the training data 𝒟𝒟{\cal D}, and TNR measures the ability to detect the absence of t𝑡t. From the result, we can see that our attack has high TPR across all scenarios, which means it is sensitive to detecting the case where t∈D𝑡𝐷t\in D. Moreover, our TNR is greater than 0.5 indicating the capability of discerning the absence of t𝑡t in the training data (except for the ImageNet dataset at ε≤4𝜀4\varepsilon\leq 4).

Training the Chosen Neuron under LDP.

Training the chosen neuron is equivalent to determining a decision boundary that can distinguish the target sample (and its randomized variants) from any other samples. Fig. 6 visualizes how the samples in the training set 𝒟𝒟{\cal D} are distributed using t-SNE [Van der Maaten and Hinton, 2008]. At ε=10𝜀10\varepsilon=10, Fig. 6(a) shows that the t-SNE algorithm is able to group together the target sample t𝑡t and its randomized variants. This is because the LDP mechanism imposes a small amount of noise such that t𝑡t and its randomized variants ℳ​(t,ε)ℳ𝑡𝜀\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon) closely resemble one another. Hence, t-SNE models these by nearby points. Therefore, it is easy for our attack to train a neuron that can distinguish ℳ​(t,ε)ℳ𝑡𝜀\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon) from other samples, resulting in an attack success rate of about 0.99 as shown in Fig. 5.

At ε=5𝜀5\varepsilon=5, Fig. 6(c) shows that ℳ​(t,ε)ℳ𝑡𝜀\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon) blends into other samples, meaning that t-SNE is unable to group together the randomized variants of t𝑡t as in the previous Fig. 6(a). This is because the mechanism ℳ​(⋅,ε)ℳ⋅𝜀\mathcal{M}(\cdot,\varepsilon) imposes a high amount of noise at ε=5𝜀5\varepsilon=5, so that all randomized variants ℳ​(t,ε)ℳ𝑡𝜀\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon) no longer closely resemble one another. This makes the task of finding the decision boundary between ℳ​(t,ε)ℳ𝑡𝜀\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon) and other samples more difficult. Nevertheless, our AMI attack can still attain a success rate of 0.80 (Fig.  5).

Certified Guarantee of Success.

Given a privacy budget ε∈[1,10]𝜀110\varepsilon\in[1,10], in order to check the certified guanrantee conditions as in Theorem 11, we obtain the the lower and upper bounds 𝔼^l​b​[v​(t)]superscript^𝔼𝑙𝑏delimited-[]𝑣𝑡\hat{\mathbb{E}}^{lb}\big{[}v(t)\big{]} and 𝔼^u​b​[v​(x)]superscript^𝔼𝑢𝑏delimited-[]𝑣𝑥\hat{\mathbb{E}}^{ub}\big{[}v(x)\big{]} (Eqs. 9 and 10) by using 4,00040004,000 ε𝜀\varepsilon-LDP target samples ℳ​(t,ε)ℳ𝑡𝜀\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon) and all ε𝜀\varepsilon-LDP non-target samples ℳ​(x,ε)ℳ𝑥𝜀\mathcal{M}(x,\varepsilon) from the validation set of each dataset. Here we use BitRand [Lai et al., 2021] as the ℳ​(⋅,ε)ℳ⋅𝜀\mathcal{M}(\cdot,\varepsilon) mechanism for the embeddings since BitRand is designed and well-suited for randomizing the embeddings.

Fig. 7 shows the certified guarantee of success for the CelebA, ImageNet, and CIFAR-10 datasets. We can derive certified guarantee of success for our AMI attack given ε≥1𝜀1\varepsilon\geq 1 with a small broken probability 10−8superscript10810^{-8}. For rigorous privacy budgets, e.g., ε≤3𝜀3\varepsilon\leq 3, the output of the chosen neuron for both the target and non-target samples approaches the borderline associated with v​(⋅)=0𝑣⋅0v(\cdot)=0 (i.e., the dotted green lines), indicating a higher chance for AMI attacks to be failed given a broken probability δ𝛿\delta. When the privacy budget ε𝜀\varepsilon increases, the output of the chosen neuron fits well with the attack objective. As a result, the expected value of the chosen neuron departs from the borderline, i.e., more positive given the target samples (i.e., the solid red lines) and more negative given the non-target samples (i.e., the solid blue lines). That implies a better attack success rate. Also, we observed that the overlapping area between the two distributions of the target samples and the non-target samples reduce significantly, which is consistent with our certified guarantee of success (Fig. 10, Appendix D) and our empirical results in Fig. 5.

6 RELATED WORK

Membership inference (MI) is one of the most fundamental privacy problems in machine learning [Carlini et al., 2022]. Several research has been carried out to convey the practical consequences of MI attacks [Backes et al., 2016, Pyrgelis et al., 2018] and analyze the models’ vulnerability to MI [Carlini et al., 2019, Song and Mittal, 2021]. Along this direction, multiple MI attacks have been proposed in which the attacker only queries the model or observes its parameters to conduct the attacks [Shokri et al., 2017, Salem et al., 2019, Carlini et al., 2022]. Such attacks can be straightforwardly adapted to FL in which the central server is a passive adversary who tries to infer the membership information of clients’ private data via inspecting their local models’ parameters [Nguyen and Thai, 2022, Melis et al., 2019]. Recently, an AMI attack in FL proposed by [Nasr et al., 2019] considers a dishonest server that can interfere with the FL training protocol. However, this attack must be repeated in multiple training iterations to attain a high success rate. Furthermore, LDP has been shown to be an effective defense against these attacks [Rahman et al., 2018, Bernau et al., 2021, Gu et al., 2022].

Our work proposes a new AMI attack in FL where the dishonest server can maliciously modify the model weights to its advantage. We have proposed a strategy that results in minimal modifications to the model and can be executed in only one training iteration. More importantly, our attack can maintain a strong success rate even when the clients’ data are protected by an LDP mechanism.

7 CONCLUSION AND DISCUSSION

In this paper, we have introduced a formal threat model for our AMI attack with dishonest FL servers, showing a more realistic privacy threat. Accordingly, we have proposed a new active membership inference (AMI) attack, exploiting the correlation among data features through a non-linear decision boundary. AMI attacks can achieve high success rates even under LDP protection, confirmed by both theoretical analysis and experimental evaluations. From this attack, our research has demonstrated that current implementations of FL provide virtually no privacy protection for clients.

With such a strong AMI attack, our future work would focus on the defenses. We discuss some challenges in devising such a solution as follows.

Noisy gradients with DPSGD. A potential defense against our attack is to let clients add DP noise to their gradients using DPSGD [Abadi et al., 2016] before sending them to the server, hindering the attacker from knowing the true value of the chosen neuron’s gradient. However, recent work [Boenisch et al., 2021, Tramèr and Boneh, 2021] suggests that using DPSGD makes it impossible to train a good model for datasets like CIFAR-10 or ImageNet. Furthermore, even if DPSGD is used, the attacker can still circumvent it by aggregating the noisy gradients over multiple FL iterations and potentially cancelling out the added DP noise. A detailed analysis on this can be found in Appendix E.

Detecting Malicious Weights is Challenging. The hardness in detecting malicious weights can be evaluated by examining the difference between malicious weights and normal weights (i.e., the weights that could be obtained from an honest server). Fig. 14 (Appendix) shows the distribution of the normal weights together with the distribution of the malicious weights when attacking under LDP protection at ε=2,3,𝜀23\varepsilon=2,3, and 555, and they largely resemble one another. Fig. 8 shows the 4 distributions using their respective kernel density estimation (KDE), which is used to visualize the shape of a data distribution, and represent the data using a continuous probability density curve. We can see that the malicious weights do not result in any abnormal distribution, making it indistinguishable from normal weights. This implies that, by observing the distribution of model weights, it is infeasible to determine whether the model weights have been modified maliciously by our attack.

Appendix A INFEASIBILITY OF LINEARITY FOR AMI

Suppose that, given the target data sample t∈ℝd𝑡superscriptℝ𝑑t\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, there exists a W𝑊W that can satisfy Eq. (4) for all x≠t𝑥𝑡x\neq t. We choose x1=t1+csubscript𝑥1subscript𝑡1𝑐x_{1}=t_{1}+c and xi=tisubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑡𝑖x_{i}=t_{i} for i>1𝑖1i>1 and c>0𝑐0c>0. Denoting w≡Wi𝑤subscript𝑊𝑖w\equiv W_{i}, from the second condition in Eq. (4), we have that:

w1​c+∑j=1dwj​tj≤0⟹−w1​c≥∑j=1dwj​tjsubscript𝑤1𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑑subscript𝑤𝑗subscript𝑡𝑗0⟹subscript𝑤1𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑑subscript𝑤𝑗subscript𝑡𝑗w_{1}c+\sum_{j=1}^{d}w_{j}t_{j}\leq 0\Longrightarrow-w_{1}c\geq\sum_{j=1}^{d}w_{j}t_{j} (13)

Likewise, choosing x1′=t1−csubscriptsuperscript𝑥′1subscript𝑡1𝑐x^{\prime}_{1}=t_{1}-c and xi′=tisubscriptsuperscript𝑥′𝑖subscript𝑡𝑖x^{\prime}_{i}=t_{i} for i>1𝑖1i>1, from the second condition in Eq. (4), we have:

−w1​c+∑j=1cwj​tj≤0⟹w1​c≥∑j=1dwj​tjsubscript𝑤1𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑐subscript𝑤𝑗subscript𝑡𝑗0⟹subscript𝑤1𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑑subscript𝑤𝑗subscript𝑡𝑗-w_{1}c+\sum_{j=1}^{c}w_{j}t_{j}\leq 0\Longrightarrow w_{1}c\geq\sum_{j=1}^{d}w_{j}t_{j} (14)

As ∑j=1dwj​tj>0superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑑subscript𝑤𝑗subscript𝑡𝑗0\sum_{j=1}^{d}w_{j}t_{j}>0 by the first condition in Eq. (4), the two equations (13) and (14) contradicts one another. Therefore, there exists no W𝑊W that can satisfy Eq. (4) for all x≠t𝑥𝑡x\neq t.

Appendix B PROOF OF THEOREM 11

Given the target sample t𝑡t and any data samples x≠ℳ​(t,ε)𝑥ℳ𝑡𝜀x\neq\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon), the AMI attack 𝒜L​D​P𝔻,ℳsubscriptsuperscript𝒜𝔻ℳ𝐿𝐷𝑃\mathcal{A}^{\mathbb{D},\mathcal{M}}_{LDP} is successful in determining the membership of t𝑡t if it can ensure that the chosen neuron is activated only by the LDP-preserving ℳ​(t,ε)ℳ𝑡𝜀\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon). Following the expected output stability property in DP [Lecuyer et al., 2019], in which the expected value of an ε𝜀\varepsilon-LDP algorithm with bounded output is not sensitive to small changes in the input, the trained attack 𝒜L​D​P𝔻,ℳsubscriptsuperscript𝒜𝔻ℳ𝐿𝐷𝑃\mathcal{A}^{\mathbb{D},\mathcal{M}}_{LDP} is certifiably robust to ℳ​(⋅,ε)ℳ⋅𝜀\mathcal{M}(\cdot,\varepsilon) if the following condition holds:

{𝔼​[v​(t)]>0𝔼​[v​(x)]≤0,x≠ℳ​(t,ε)\left\{\begin{aligned} &\mathbb{E}\big{[}v(t)\big{]}>0\\ &\mathbb{E}\big{[}v(x)\big{]}\leq 0,\quad x\neq\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon)\end{aligned}\right. (15)

where v​(t)=h⋅ReLU⁡(W​ℳ​(t,ε))𝑣𝑡⋅ℎReLU𝑊ℳ𝑡𝜀v(t)=h\cdot\operatorname{ReLU}(W\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon)) and v​(x)=h⋅ReLU⁡(W​x)𝑣𝑥⋅ℎReLU𝑊𝑥v(x)=h\cdot\operatorname{ReLU}(Wx) are the values of the chosen neuron, given the randomized target sample ℳ​(t,ε)ℳ𝑡𝜀\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon) and any other data samples x≠ℳ​(t,ε)𝑥ℳ𝑡𝜀x\neq\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon), respectively.

However, due to the potentially complex nature of the post-noise computation, we cannot precisely compute the expectations in Eq. 8. We therefore resort to Monte Carlo sampling to estimate the expectations 𝔼^​(⋅)^𝔼⋅\hat{\mathbb{E}}(\cdot). This estimation is obtained by invoking ℳ​(⋅)ℳ⋅\mathcal{M}(\cdot) multiple times with independent draws of the noise over the input. We denote vp​(t)subscript𝑣𝑝𝑡v_{p}(t) as the p𝑝p draws of ℳ​(t,ε)ℳ𝑡𝜀\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon) from the target sample t𝑡t and vq​(x)subscript𝑣𝑞𝑥v_{q}(x) as the q𝑞q draws of ℳ​(x,ε)ℳ𝑥𝜀\mathcal{M}(x,\varepsilon) from the sample x𝑥x.

Denoting Range⁡(v​(⋅))Range𝑣⋅\operatorname{Range}\big{(}v(\cdot)\big{)} as the range of v​(⋅)𝑣⋅v(\cdot), v​(⋅)∈Range⁡(v​(⋅))𝑣⋅Range𝑣⋅v(\cdot)\in\operatorname{Range}\big{(}v(\cdot)\big{)}. In other words, v​(⋅)𝑣⋅v(\cdot) is bounded in Range⁡(v​(⋅))Range𝑣⋅\operatorname{Range}\big{(}v(\cdot)\big{)}. Given a broken probability δ𝛿\delta, using Hoeffding’s inequality, with t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0 we have:

P​((1p​∑i=1pv​(t))−𝔼​[v​(t)]≥t)𝑃1𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑝𝑣𝑡𝔼delimited-[]𝑣𝑡𝑡\displaystyle P\Big{(}(\frac{1}{p}\sum_{i=1}^{p}v(t))-\mathbb{E}[v(t)]\geq t\Big{)} =P​(1p​∑i=1p(v​(t)−𝔼​[v​(t)])≥t)absent𝑃1𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑝𝑣𝑡𝔼delimited-[]𝑣𝑡𝑡\displaystyle=P\Big{(}\frac{1}{p}\sum_{i=1}^{p}\big{(}v(t)-\mathbb{E}[v(t)]\big{)}\geq t\Big{)}
≤exp⁡(−2​p​t21p∑i=1pRange(v(t))2)=exp⁡(−2​p​t2Range(v(t))2)\displaystyle\leq\exp\Big{(}-\frac{2pt^{2}}{\frac{1}{p}\sum_{i=1}^{p}\operatorname{Range}\big{(}v(t)\big{)}^{2}}\Big{)}=\exp\Big{(}-\frac{2pt^{2}}{\operatorname{Range}\big{(}v(t)\big{)}^{2}}\Big{)} (16)

As mentioned in Section 4, we replace 𝔼​[v​(t)]𝔼delimited-[]𝑣𝑡\mathbb{E}[v(t)] in Eq. 16 with 𝔼^​[v​(t)]^𝔼delimited-[]𝑣𝑡\hat{\mathbb{E}}[v(t)]. Given a broken probability δ𝛿\delta, we have:

exp⁡(−2​p​t2Range(v(t))2)=δ⇔t=Range⁡(v​(t))​−ln⁡(δ)2​p\displaystyle\exp\Big{(}-\frac{2pt^{2}}{\operatorname{Range}(v(t))^{2}}\Big{)}=\delta\Leftrightarrow t=\operatorname{Range}\big{(}v(t)\big{)}\sqrt{-\frac{\ln(\delta)}{2p}} (17)

Similarly, with the non-target samples, we have:

t=Range⁡(v​(x))​−ln⁡(δ)2​q𝑡Range𝑣𝑥𝛿2𝑞t=\operatorname{Range}\big{(}v(x)\big{)}\sqrt{-\frac{\ln(\delta)}{2q}} (18)

By leveraging the Monte Carlo sampling for the expectation estimation, we can replace 𝔼​[v​(t)]𝔼delimited-[]𝑣𝑡\mathbb{E}\big{[}v(t)\big{]} with 𝔼^​[v​(t)]=1p​∑pvp​(t)^𝔼delimited-[]𝑣𝑡1𝑝subscript𝑝subscript𝑣𝑝𝑡\hat{\mathbb{E}}\big{[}v(t)\big{]}=\frac{1}{p}\sum_{p}v_{p}(t) and replace 𝔼​[v​(x)]𝔼delimited-[]𝑣𝑥\mathbb{E}\big{[}v(x)\big{]} with 𝔼^​[v​(x)]=1q​∑qvq​(x)^𝔼delimited-[]𝑣𝑥1𝑞subscript𝑞subscript𝑣𝑞𝑥\hat{\mathbb{E}}\big{[}v(x)\big{]}=\frac{1}{q}\sum_{q}v_{q}(x), where p𝑝p an q𝑞q are the number of invocations of ℳ​(⋅)ℳ⋅\mathcal{M}(\cdot) for t𝑡t and x𝑥x, respectively.

The key idea is to simultaneously ensure that the lower bound 𝔼^l​b​[v​(t)]superscript^𝔼𝑙𝑏delimited-[]𝑣𝑡\hat{\mathbb{E}}^{lb}\big{[}v(t)\big{]} is larger than 00 and the upper bound 𝔼^u​b​[v​(x)]superscript^𝔼𝑢𝑏delimited-[]𝑣𝑥\hat{\mathbb{E}}^{ub}\big{[}v(x)\big{]} is smaller than or equal to 00 with a broken probability δ𝛿\delta. That provides a certified guarantee for the Eq. (8) to hold. From Eqs. 17 and 18, we can compute (1−δ)1𝛿(1-\delta)-confidence the lower bound 𝔼^l​b​[v​(t)]superscript^𝔼𝑙𝑏delimited-[]𝑣𝑡\hat{\mathbb{E}}^{lb}\big{[}v(t)\big{]} and the upper bound 𝔼^u​b​[v​(x)]superscript^𝔼𝑢𝑏delimited-[]𝑣𝑥\hat{\mathbb{E}}^{ub}\big{[}v(x)\big{]}, as follows:

𝔼^l​b​[v​(t)]≜𝔼^​[v​(t)]−Range⁡(v​(t))​−ln⁡(δ)2​p≜superscript^𝔼𝑙𝑏delimited-[]𝑣𝑡^𝔼delimited-[]𝑣𝑡Range𝑣𝑡𝛿2𝑝\displaystyle\hat{\mathbb{E}}^{lb}\big{[}v(t)\big{]}\triangleq\hat{\mathbb{E}}\big{[}v(t)\big{]}-\operatorname{Range}\big{(}v(t)\big{)}\sqrt{-\frac{\ln(\delta)}{2p}} (19)
𝔼^u​b​[v​(x)]≜𝔼^​[v​(x)]+Range⁡(v​(x))​−ln⁡(δ)2​q≜superscript^𝔼𝑢𝑏delimited-[]𝑣𝑥^𝔼delimited-[]𝑣𝑥Range𝑣𝑥𝛿2𝑞\displaystyle\hat{\mathbb{E}}^{ub}\big{[}v(x)\big{]}\triangleq\hat{\mathbb{E}}\big{[}v(x)\big{]}+\operatorname{Range}\big{(}v(x)\big{)}\sqrt{-\frac{\ln(\delta)}{2q}} (20)

By replacing the bounds in Eqs. 19 and 20 to the expectations in Eq. 15, we we derive the certified guarantee so that Eq. (15) holds. In other words, The AMI attack 𝒜L​D​P𝔻,ℳsubscriptsuperscript𝒜𝔻ℳ𝐿𝐷𝑃\mathcal{A}^{\mathbb{D},\mathcal{M}}_{LDP} is successful in inferring the membership of the target sample t𝑡t in 𝔻𝔻\mathbb{D} if the following condition is satisfied:

{𝔼^l​b​[v​(t)]>0𝔼^u​b​[v​(x)]≤0,x≠ℳ​(t,ε)\left\{\begin{aligned} &\hat{\mathbb{E}}^{lb}\big{[}v(t)\big{]}>0\\ &\hat{\mathbb{E}}^{ub}\big{[}v(x)\big{]}\leq 0,\quad x\neq\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon)\end{aligned}\right. (21)

Consequently, Theorem 11 holds.

Appendix C OME [Lyu et al., 2020] AND BITRAND [Lai et al., 2021]

Apart from applying LDP-preserving mechanisms in real values of inputs or gradients [Warner, 1965, Zhao et al., 2020, Wang et al., 2019], there is a line of work introducing LDP-preserving mechanisms to inputs or embedding features [Lai et al., 2021, Lyu et al., 2020, Arachchige et al., 2019]. In these mechanisms, they encode the original data or embedding features into binary vectors, then apply the LDP mechanisms on top of the binary vectors, before training the local models.

In OME, each bit i𝑖i is randomized differently depending on whether it is the odd or even bit or it is bit 00 or 111, as follows:

∀i∈[0,rl−1]:P(vx′(i)=1)={p1​X=α1+α, if ​i∈2​j,vx​(i)=1p2​X=11+α3, if ​i∈2​j+1,vx​(i)=1qX=11+α​exp⁡(εr​l), if ​vx​(i)=0\displaystyle\forall i\in[0,rl-1]:P(v^{\prime}_{x}(i)=1)=\left\{\begin{aligned} &p_{1X}=\frac{\alpha}{1+\alpha},\text{ if }i\in 2j,v_{x}(i)=1\\ &p_{2X}=\frac{1}{1+\alpha^{3}},\text{ if }i\in 2j+1,v_{x}(i)=1\\ &q_{X}=\frac{1}{1+\alpha\exp(\frac{\varepsilon}{rl})},\text{ if }\ v_{x}(i)=0\end{aligned}\right. (22)

where ε𝜀\varepsilon the total privacy budget.

This mechanism is similar to the Utility enhancing randomization (UER) mechanism (Theorem III.4 [Arachchige et al., 2019]). As shown in [Arachchige et al., 2019, Lyu et al., 2020], model accuracy is almost constant although ε𝜀\varepsilon is changed.

However, existing LDP mechanisms suffer from the curse of privacy composition in which excessive privacy budgets are consumed proportionally to the large dimensions of input or embedded features [Arachchige et al., 2019], gradients [Zhao et al., 2020, Wang et al., 2019], and training rounds [Zhao et al., 2020, Wang et al., 2019], causing loose privacy protection or inferior model accuracy [Wagh et al., 2021].

To mitigate the curse of privacy composition and to optimize the trade-off among privacy and model utility, [Lai et al., 2021] introduce bit-aware term i%​llpercent𝑖𝑙𝑙\frac{i\%l}{l} and a temperature α𝛼\alpha for better control of the randomization probabilities. In BitRand, the randomization probabilities are adaptively randomized such that “bits with a more substantial impact” on model utility will have ”smaller randomization probabilities (less noisy)” and vice-versa under the same privacy budget, as follows:

∀i∈[0,rl−1]:P(vx′(i)=1)={pX=11+α​exp⁡(i%​ll​ε), if​vx​(i)=1qX=α​exp⁡(i%​ll​ε)1+α​exp⁡(i%​ll​ε), if​vx​(i)=0\displaystyle\forall i\in[0,rl-1]:P(v^{\prime}_{x}(i)=1)=\left\{\begin{aligned} &p_{X}=\frac{1}{1+\alpha\exp(\frac{i\%l}{l}\varepsilon)},\text{ if}\ v_{x}(i)=1\\ &q_{X}=\frac{\alpha\exp(\frac{i\%l}{l}\varepsilon)}{1+\alpha\exp(\frac{i\%l}{l}\varepsilon)},\text{ if}\ v_{x}(i)=0\end{aligned}\right. (23)

where vx​(i)∈{0,1}subscript𝑣𝑥𝑖01v_{x}(i)\in\{0,1\} is the value of vxsubscript𝑣𝑥v_{x} at the bit i𝑖i, vx′subscriptsuperscript𝑣′𝑥v^{\prime}_{x} is the perturbed vector created by randomizing all the bits in vxsubscript𝑣𝑥v_{x}, ε𝜀\varepsilon is a privacy budget, and α𝛼\alpha is a parameter bounded with 0<α≤ε+r​l2​r​∑i=0l−1exp⁡(2​εl​i%​l)0𝛼𝜀𝑟𝑙2𝑟superscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑙12𝜀𝑙percent𝑖𝑙0<\alpha\leq\sqrt{\frac{\varepsilon+rl}{2r\sum_{i=0}^{l-1}\exp(2\frac{\varepsilon}{l}i\%l)}}. The bit-aware term i%​llpercent𝑖𝑙𝑙\frac{i\%l}{l} to indicate the location of bit i𝑖i, which is associated with the sensitivity of the bit at that location, in its l𝑙l-bit binary encoded vector among r​l𝑟𝑙rl concatenated binary bits.

Appendix D ADDITIONAL EXPERIMENTS

This section provides more details on the experimental settings, and presents additional experiments.

Settings.

Our experiments in this paper are implemented using Python 3.8 and conducted on a single GPU-assisted compute node that is installed with a Linux 64-bit operating system. The allocated resources include 8 CPU cores (AMD EPYC 7742 model) with 2 threads per core, and 60GB of RAM. The node is also equipped with 8 GPUs (NVIDIA DGX A100 SuperPod model), with 80GB of memory per GPU.

The model accuracies in Figs. 5 and 11 are measured by evaluating the model on legitimate classification tasks. For the CelebA dataset [Liu et al., 2015], the task is to classify whether a person is smiling or not based on face images. With regard to the CIFAR-10 dataset [Krizhevsky et al., 2009], we use its original classification task with 10 classes. For the ImageNet dataset [Deng et al., 2009], we extract a subset of 10 classes: tench, English springer, cassette player, chain saw, church, French horn, garbage truck, gas pump, golf ball, and parachute111https://github.com/fastai/imagenette. Then, we evaluate the model performance on classifying those 10 classes.

To obtain the feature embeddings of data samples, we use the pre-trained Resnet-18 model from Img2Vec222https://github.com/christiansafka/img2vec.

Attack performance without LDP.

In this setting, the attack strategy in Fig. 2 requires the attacker to train the malicious parameters h,Wℎ𝑊h,W, which takes multiple local training epochs. Fig. 9 shows the attack success rate per local epoch with 2,000 neurons in the first layer (r=2,000𝑟2000r=2,000). As can be seen, over time, the attack success rate reaches 100% across all three datasets. Table 1 shows the average number of local training epochs needed to train those parameters to achieve the 100% success rate, as we vary r𝑟r. We observe that increasing r𝑟r helps the attacker find the optimal parameters h,Wℎ𝑊h,W faster. For CIFAR-10, with r=2,000𝑟2000r=2,000 neurons in the first layer, the attacker can easily train h,Wℎ𝑊h,W within 50 epochs.

To understand the reason behind this behavior, we note that training h,Wℎ𝑊h,W in this attack strategy is equivalent to finding a non-linear decision boundary that overfits to the target sample t𝑡t (Eq. 5), thereby distinguishing the target sample t𝑡t from any other samples. Hence, increasing r𝑟r raises the chance of over-fitting which, in turn, shortens the time to find h,Wℎ𝑊h,W. Furthermore, Table 1 indicates that as few as r=5𝑟5r=5 neurons are needed to attain the 100% success rate, albeit the longer training time.

Attack performance under LDP.

To shed light into how the privacy budget ε𝜀\varepsilon in the LDP mechanism, i.e., BitRand, affects the AMI success rate, we visualize the distribution of the values of the chosen neuron associated with the target and non-target samples. In Fig. 10(a), with rigorous privacy budget (e.g., ε=1𝜀1\varepsilon=1), the mean values of the chosen neuron is positive given the target samples and negative given the non-target samples. However, there is a notable overlap in the two distributions of the target samples (i.e., red distribution) and the non-target samples (i.e., blue distribution). This makes the attack difficult in distinguishing the target and non-target samples, based on the value of the chosen neuron. Consequently, the attack success rate is moderate. On the other hand, when ε𝜀\varepsilon increases (Figs. 10(b)-10(d)), the distribution of the target samples shift to the right, meanwhile the distribution of the non-target samples shift to the left. The shifts result in a less overlap between the two distributions. As a result, when the privacy budget ε𝜀\varepsilon increases, the attack success rate of AMI increases. We observe this phenomenon in all three datasets.

In addition to evaluating the attack under the BitRand mechanism in Section 5, Fig. 11 shows our attack performance under the OME mechanism [Lyu et al., 2020]. First, we observe the same phenomenon of OME as in [Arachchige et al., 2019, Lyu et al., 2020] in which the model accuracy does not change much for ε∈[1,10]𝜀110\varepsilon\in[1,10]. Second, our attack maintains a severe success rate of about 90% for CelebA and CIFAR-10. More importantly, the attack success rate reaches more than 95% for ImageNet. These results demonstrate that our AMI attack remains very effective even with low privacy budget ε𝜀\varepsilon when the training set 𝒟𝒟{\cal D} is protected by the OME mechanism.

Fig. 12 shows the certified guarantee of success for the CelebA, ImageNet, and CIFAR-10 datasets when the LDP-preserving OME mechanism is used. We can derive a certified guarantee of success for our AMI attack given ε≥1𝜀1\varepsilon\geq 1 with a small broken probability 10−8superscript10810^{-8}. This result is consistent with our attack success rate reported in Fig. 11. In addition to the unaffected model accuracy and attack success rate, the effect of the privacy budget ε𝜀\varepsilon is modest in the certified guarantee of success, given ε∈[1,10]𝜀110\varepsilon\in[1,10] used in OME.

Appendix E NOISY GRADIENTS WITH DPSGD

Aside from LDP where clients perturb their own local training data 𝒟𝒟{\cal D} before computing the gradients, another method is to let clients add DP noise to their gradients using DPSGD [Abadi et al., 2016] before sending them to the server, hindering the attacker from knowing the true value of the chosen neuron’s gradient gtsubscript𝑔𝑡g_{t}. Nevertheless, recent work suggests that using DPSGD makes it impossible to train models with reasonable accuracy for datasets like CIFAR-10 or ImageNet, even in a non-distributed setting [Boenisch et al., 2021, Tramèr and Boneh, 2021].

Moreover, even when DPSGD is used to add noise to the gradients, we can leverage the fact that the FL training is done in multiple iterations to circumvent this DP noise. In [Abadi et al., 2016], the DP noise is sampled from a zero-mean Gaussian distribution with a standard deviation of σ=2​ln⁡(1.25/δ)ε𝜎21.25𝛿𝜀\sigma=\frac{\sqrt{2\ln(1.25/\delta)}}{\varepsilon}, where ε𝜀\varepsilon is the privacy budget and δ𝛿\delta is a broken probability. However, as the noise is zero-mean, averaging the noise samples over multiple iterations will cancel out the noise and reveal the true value of the gradients. This is also referred to as the privacy composition problem in DP [Dwork et al., 2014].

Specifically, denoting gt(i)′=gt+zisuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝑡superscript𝑖′subscript𝑔𝑡subscript𝑧𝑖g_{t}^{(i)^{\prime}}=g_{t}+z_{i} (where zi∼𝒩​(0,σ2​𝐈)similar-tosubscript𝑧𝑖𝒩0superscript𝜎2𝐈z_{i}\sim{\cal N}(0,\sigma^{2}\mathbf{I})) as the noisy gradient of the chosen neuron at iteration i𝑖i, the server can obtain the true gradient gtsubscript𝑔𝑡g_{t} by averaging over multiple iterations, i.e., gt=1P​∑i=1Pgt(i)′subscript𝑔𝑡1𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑡superscript𝑖′g_{t}=\frac{1}{P}\sum_{i=1}^{P}g_{t}^{(i)^{\prime}}. From this gtsubscript𝑔𝑡g_{t}, the attacker can determine whether the target sample was used in at least one of those iterations, following the same principle in Section 3. Fig. 13(a) shows the number of iterations needed to eliminate the DP noise. Previous work shows that training a neural network for CIFAR-10 up to a modest accuracy of 66.2% requires a privacy budget ε≥7.53𝜀7.53\varepsilon\geq 7.53 [Tramèr and Boneh, 2021], hence we evaluate with ε≥7.5𝜀7.5\varepsilon\geq 7.5. When ε≥8𝜀8\varepsilon\geq 8, we need less than 100 iterations.

To reduce the number of iterations, we can increase the number of chosen neurons in the second layer, and average the noisy gradients over all of the chosen neurons. Simply speaking, having K𝐾K chosen neurons would reduce the number of iterations by K𝐾K-fold. Fig. 13(b) shows the number of iterations needed to eliminate the DP noise with multiple neurons. As can be seen, with only 4 chosen neurons, we only need less than 60 iterations to cancel out the DP noise at ε=7.5𝜀7.5\varepsilon=7.5. With 8 chosen neurons, the noise can be canceled out within 10 iterations.
